metadata.case_name: Durgah Committee, Ajmer & Anr. v. Khadims (Syed Hussain Ali & Ors.)

facts.text: Khwaja Moin-ud-din Chishti died in Ajmer in or about 1236 A.D., and a kutcha tomb was constructed immediately after his death.
Pucca structure of the tomb built by Khilji Sultans of Mandu, over which successive Muslim rulers, particularly Mughal Emperors, made endowments.

Khwaja Syed Fukhuruddin and Sheikh Mohammad Yadgar, descendants who accompanied Khwaja Saheb, looked after the grave and spiritual needs of pilgrims after his death; their descendants became known as Khadims.
Khadims performed religious services at the tomb, kept keys, attended pilgrims, acted as spiritual guides for Fateha, received Nazars (offerings) as main source of income.
Rights of Khadims to offerings decided by Privy Council in Syed Altaf Hussain v. Dewan Syed Ali Rasul Ali Khan (AIR 1938 PC 71), recognizing customary division between Sajjadanashin and Khadims.
Shrine visited by Muslims, Hindus, Khoja Memons, Parsis; not confined to Chishtia Order.
Khadims are servants/chowkidars of the tomb, no right to offerings; offerings meant for poor/indigent per Islamic belief.
High Court writ petition under Art. 226 by nine Khadims challenging vires of Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act XXXVI of 1955; succeeded, declared sections ultra vires, restrained enforcement.
Akbar endowed 18 villages in 1575 for langar khana; appointed Sajjadanashin as Mutawalli.
Shah Jahan separated office of Sajjadanashin from Mutawalli (Darogah); endowed villages for general purposes; Mutawalli appointed by State.
Management of Durgah endowments always by State-appointed Mutawallis, answerable to State; sometimes Hindus held post.
Act XX of 1863 transferred management from Revenue Boards to trustees/committees.
Act XXIII of 1936 provided for Durgah Committee management.
Ghulam Hasan Committee (1949) inquired into administration, found malpractices by Sajjadanashins and Khadims, recommended reforms leading to 1955 Act.
Privy Council in Asrar Ahmed v. Durgah Committee (AIR 1947 PC 1) held Mutawalli office as State appointment, not hereditary.
Detailed affidavit by Syed Mohammed Hanis on daily duties of Khadims: opening gates, prayers, cleaning, guiding pilgrims, receiving Nazars, etc.
Judicial Commissioner (1931) findings on division of offerings: specific to Durgah, outside dome to Khadims, inside shared, etc.; affirmed by Privy Council.

legal_issues.text: Whether provisions of Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 (esp. ss. 2(b)(v), 5, 11(f), 11(b), 13(1), 14, 16, 18) are ultra vires Arts. 14, 19(1)(f)(g), 25, 26, 31(1)(2), 32.
Whether Chishtia Soofies constitute a religious denomination entitled to manage Durgah under Art. 26.
Whether Khadims have fundamental right to offerings/Nazars under Art. 19(1)(f), and if Act diverts them.

petitioner_arguments.text: Shrine not confined to Chishtia Order; visited by diverse pilgrims; Khadims mere servants/chowkidars without rights to premises/keys/offerings.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Islamic belief on offerings for poor

petitioner_arguments.text: Historical management by State-appointed Mutawallis; endowments not for denomination; Act intra vires.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 26 does not create new rights

petitioner_arguments.text: Ghulam Hasan Committee found malpractices by Khadims/Sajjadanashins justifying reforms.

respondent_arguments.text: Khadims of Chishtia Soofies order have hereditary rights to manage shrine, receive Nazars; Act abridges fundamental rights to property and religious management.
s.5 allows non-Chishti Hanafi Muslims in Committee, violating Art. 26.
Offerings customarily divided per judicial decisions; Act diverts them via s.2(d)(v), s.14.

court_reasoning.text: Historical review shows management always by State-appointed Mutawallis, not denomination; Art. 26 safeguards existing rights, does not create new ones.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Endowments conditioned on State management; no denominational right.

court_reasoning.text: Chishtia Soofies not a separate sect but silsila within Hanafi Muslims; assume denomination for argument but no management right historically.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sufism is mystic attitude, not separate religion.

court_reasoning.text: Offerings for Durgah (earmarked) always belonged to it per Judicial Commissioner/Privy Council; s.2(d)(v), s.14 regulate only those, not Khadims' share.
s.11(f)(h) regulate secular duties/privileges, subject to s.15 (Muslim law/tenets); s.16 arbitrates secular disputes only.
s.5 not invalid; narrow challenge fails as whole Committee invalid if violates Art.26(d), but no such right.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot cure by limiting to denomination.

holdings.text: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 intra vires; no violation of Arts. 19, 25, 26; High Court erred in striking down sections.
Art. 26(c)(d) protects only existing rights to administer property; denomination had none over endowments.
Khadims' rights to non-Durgah offerings unaffected; regulation of solicitation for Durgah valid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Syed Altaf Hussain v. Dewan Syed Ali Rasul Ali Khan
precedents_cited.relevance: Customary division of offerings; Durgah entitled to earmarked offerings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Asrar Ahmed v. Durgah Committee, Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Mutawalli office is State appointment, not hereditary.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner, Hindu Religious Endowments, Madras v. Sri Lakshmindra Thirtha Swamiar of Sri Shirur Mutt
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of religious denomination; matters of religion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Venkataramana Devaru v. State of Mysore
precedents_cited.relevance: Practices integral to religion protected under Art. 26(b).
Functions of Sajjadanashin as spiritual preceptor.

statutes_cited.name: Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates administration of Durgah Endowment; upheld as constitutional.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged provisions do not violate fundamental rights.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court judgment declaring sections of Durgah Khwaja Saheb Act, 1955 ultra vires, held Act constitutional and intra vires, restraining order quashed.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; High Court declaration and restraint order set aside.

key_quotes.text: "Art. 26(c) and (d) do not create rights in any denomination or its section which it never had they merely safeguard and guarantee the continuance of rights which such denomination or its section had."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of Art. 26.

key_quotes.text: Offerings made at the tomb for nearly 400 years before the tomb was rebuilt into a pucca structure must have been used by the Khadims for themselves.
key_quotes.speaker: high_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court finding on historical use, rejected by SC.

key_quotes.text: "The management of the properties endowed was always in the hands of officers appointed by the State who were answerable to the State."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Historical basis for upholding State control.
